title: Ezekiel Chapter 11 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Ezekiel chapter 11 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Ezekiel Chapter 11 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Ezekiel Chapter 11.

questions.question: Who were among the twenty-five men at the east gate of the LORD's house that Ezekiel saw?
options: Jaazaniah the son of Azur and Pelatiah the son of Benaiah
Daniel and Ezekiel
Moses and Aaron
David and Solomon
questions.correctAnswer: Jaazaniah the son of Azur and Pelatiah the son of Benaiah
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:1 mentions that Ezekiel saw Jaazaniah the son of Azur and Pelatiah the son of Benaiah among the twenty-five men at the east gate.

questions.question: What did the men at the gate devise according to Ezekiel 11?
options: Mischief and wicked counsel
Peace and unity
Feasts and celebrations
New laws
questions.correctAnswer: Mischief and wicked counsel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:2 states that these men devise mischief and give wicked counsel in the city.

questions.question: What metaphor did the men at the gate use to describe the city and themselves?
options: The city is the caldron, and we be the flesh
The city is a garden, and we are the flowers
The city is a fortress, and we are the stones
The city is a ship, and we are the sailors
questions.correctAnswer: The city is the caldron, and we be the flesh
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:3 quotes the men saying the city is the caldron, and they are the flesh.

questions.question: What did the Spirit of the LORD command Ezekiel to do to the men at the gate?
options: Prophesy against them
Build houses with them
Join their counsel
Celebrate their plans
questions.correctAnswer: Prophesy against them
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:4 commands Ezekiel to prophesy against those men.

questions.question: What did the LORD say He knows about the house of Israel?
options: The things that come into their mind, every one of them
Their outward appearances
Their wealth and possessions
Their enemies
questions.correctAnswer: The things that come into their mind, every one of them
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:5 states the LORD knows the thoughts of the house of Israel.

questions.question: What had the people multiplied in the city according to Ezekiel 11?
options: Slain
Harvests
Buildings
Enemies
questions.correctAnswer: Slain
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:6 says they have multiplied their slain in the city and filled the streets with the slain.

questions.question: What will the LORD bring upon the people because they feared the sword?
options: A sword
Peace
Rain
Fire
questions.correctAnswer: A sword
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:8 says the LORD will bring a sword upon them because they feared it.

questions.question: What happened to Pelatiah the son of Benaiah when Ezekiel prophesied?
options: He died
He fled the city
He repented
He was exalted
questions.correctAnswer: He died
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:13 states that Pelatiah died when Ezekiel prophesied.

questions.question: How does God describe Himself to the scattered house of Israel?
options: As a little sanctuary in the countries where they shall come
As a mighty warrior
As a consuming fire
As a distant king
questions.correctAnswer: As a little sanctuary in the countries where they shall come
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:16 says God will be like a little sanctuary to the scattered Israelites.

questions.question: What will God give the people according to Ezekiel 11:19?
options: One heart and a new spirit
Wealth and power
Stone tablets
A strong army
questions.correctAnswer: One heart and a new spirit
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:19 says God will give them one heart and put a new spirit within them.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 11:12 says the people have walked in God's statutes and executed His judgments.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:12 states that the people have not walked in God's statutes nor executed His judgments.

questions.question: True or False: The glory of the LORD went up from the midst of the city and stood upon the mountain on the east side.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:23 confirms that the glory of the LORD went up and stood upon the mountain east of the city.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel was brought in a vision by the Spirit of God into Chaldea to the captives.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:24 states that the spirit took Ezekiel in a vision to Chaldea, to those in captivity.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Ezekiel 11:20: 'That they may walk in my statutes, and keep mine ordinances, and do them: and they shall be my people, and I will be their ______.'
options: God
King
Judge
Savior
questions.correctAnswer: God
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:20 ends with God saying He will be their God.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 11:15, who are the brethren and kindred to whom the inhabitants of Jerusalem said, 'Get you far from the LORD'?
options: The men of Ezekiel's kindred and all the house of Israel
The Babylonians
The Egyptians
The Philistines
questions.correctAnswer: The men of Ezekiel's kindred and all the house of Israel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:15 identifies Ezekiel's brethren and all the house of Israel as those rejected by Jerusalem.

medium.title: Ezekiel Chapter 11 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Ezekiel Chapter 11 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is discouraged by the consequences of sin and doubts God's plan for restoration. Based on Ezekiel 11, what biblical truth would you share about God's promise?
options: God will gather His scattered people and give them a new heart and spirit
God will abandon His people forever for their sins
God will allow sin to continue without intervention
God will punish the righteous along with the wicked
questions.correctAnswer: God will gather His scattered people and give them a new heart and spirit
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:16-20 explains that although God has scattered Israel, He will be a sanctuary and gather them from the nations, giving them a new heart and spirit to follow His statutes.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 11 teach us about obedience and walking in God's statutes in daily life?
options: Obedience to God's statutes leads to being His people and experiencing His blessings
Obedience is optional and has no real consequences
Walking after the ways of heathen nations is acceptable
Ignoring God's laws leads to prosperity
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience to God's statutes leads to being His people and experiencing His blessings
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:19-20 states that God will give a new heart so that people may walk in His statutes and be His people, showing the importance of obedience for a faithful life.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with fear of judgment. Based on Ezekiel 11, what encouragement about God's justice and mercy can you offer?
options: God will judge the wicked but also deliver and bring forth a remnant
God ignores sin and does not judge
God punishes the righteous instead of the wicked
Fear is unnecessary because judgment is delayed indefinitely
questions.correctAnswer: God will judge the wicked but also deliver and bring forth a remnant
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:7-11 explains that God will bring judgment on those who do evil but will also bring forth His people from the midst of trouble, balancing justice with deliverance.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 11 instruct us about trusting God's timing in trials and restoration?
options: God's timing may involve scattering but ultimately includes gathering and restoration
God immediately fixes all problems without delay
Trials mean God has abandoned His people permanently
Restoration happens only if people ignore God's laws
questions.correctAnswer: God's timing may involve scattering but ultimately includes gathering and restoration
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:16-17 shows that although God scattered Israel, He promises to gather them again and restore them, teaching trust in His sovereign timing.

questions.question: Based on Ezekiel 11, what biblical principle can guide a believer who is tempted to conform to worldly ways?
options: Do not follow the manners of the heathen but obey God's statutes
Conform to the surrounding culture for acceptance
Ignore God's laws when pressured by others
Compromise faith to avoid conflict
questions.correctAnswer: Do not follow the manners of the heathen but obey God's statutes
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:12 warns against following the customs of surrounding peoples and emphasizes walking in God's statutes, highlighting the call to holy obedience.

questions.question: A believer asks about the role of prayer and spiritual discipline when facing hardship. What does Ezekiel 11 teach about God's Spirit and guidance?
options: The Spirit of the LORD empowers and directs for obedient proclamation and living
Spiritual discipline is unnecessary during hardship
God's Spirit only acts through miraculous signs
Prayer is futile in times of trouble
questions.correctAnswer: The Spirit of the LORD empowers and directs for obedient proclamation and living
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:4-5 describes the Spirit of the LORD falling upon Ezekiel, enabling him to prophesy and speak God's word, showing the importance of Spirit-led obedience and discipline.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 11 encourage humility and dependence on God amid judgment?
options: Recognize that judgment comes because of disobedience and seek God's mercy
Blame others and refuse to repent
Ignore God's warnings and continue sinning
Trust in personal strength to avoid consequences
questions.correctAnswer: Recognize that judgment comes because of disobedience and seek God's mercy
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:6-8 reveals that the people's slain and fear show consequences of sin, encouraging humility and turning to God for deliverance.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezekiel 11, God will completely reject and destroy all of Israel without any hope of restoration.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:16-17 shows that although Israel is scattered, God promises to be a sanctuary and gather His people, offering hope of restoration.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 11 teaches that God will give His people a new heart and spirit so they may obey Him.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:19-20 clearly states that God will remove the stony heart and give a heart of flesh and a new spirit so His people can walk in His statutes and be His people.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Ezekiel 11:23 says, 'And the glory of the LORD went up from the midst of the city, and stood upon the mountain which is on the _____ side of the city.'
options: east
west
north
south
questions.correctAnswer: east
questions.explanation: The verse Ezekiel 11:23 specifies that the glory of the LORD stood upon the mountain on the east side of the city.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 11 instruct believers about the importance of integrity and honesty in counsel and leadership?
options: Wicked counsel leads to mischief and judgment from God
Deceptive advice is acceptable for personal gain
Ignoring God's word has no consequences in leadership
Leaders should follow their own plans regardless of God's statutes
questions.correctAnswer: Wicked counsel leads to mischief and judgment from God
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:1-2 introduces men who devise mischief and give wicked counsel, leading to God's judgment, emphasizing the need for integrity and obedience in leadership.

questions.question: What biblical truth about perseverance through trials can be drawn from Ezekiel 11 regarding God's people?
options: God will bring His people through trials and ultimately deliver them
Trials mean God has forsaken His people
Endurance is unnecessary because God removes all problems instantly
Faithfulness is irrelevant during hardship
questions.correctAnswer: God will bring His people through trials and ultimately deliver them
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:7-9 promises deliverance from the midst of judgment and captivity, encouraging perseverance and trust in God's sovereign plan.

questions.question: Based on Ezekiel 11, what can we learn about the importance of repentance and turning from abominations?
options: Repentance leads to walking in God's statutes and being His people
Continuing in abominations brings judgment upon oneself
Ignoring sin results in blessing
Abominations are tolerated by God
questions.correctAnswer: Repentance leads to walking in God's statutes and being His people
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:18-21 teaches that removing detestable things and receiving a new heart enables obedience, while those who continue in sin receive recompense.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 11 demonstrate the role of spiritual vision and revelation in encouraging believers to witness and serve?
options: God reveals visions to motivate proclamation and sharing His message with captives
Spiritual visions are irrelevant to daily Christian life
Believers should keep spiritual revelations to themselves
Visions replace the need for practical ministry
questions.correctAnswer: God reveals visions to motivate proclamation and sharing His message with captives
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:24-25 shows that the Spirit brought Ezekiel in vision to the captivity and he spoke all God had shown him, illustrating the call to witness and serve others.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with contentment in difficult circumstances. What encouragement from Ezekiel 11 can you share regarding God's presence?
options: God promises to be a sanctuary even when His people are scattered
Contentment comes from worldly success, not God
God abandons those in captivity
Presence of God depends on visible blessings only
questions.correctAnswer: God promises to be a sanctuary even when His people are scattered
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:16 explains that God will be a little sanctuary in the countries where His people are scattered, encouraging contentment in His presence despite hardship.

hard.title: Ezekiel Chapter 11 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Ezekiel Chapter 11.

questions.question: Who were the two princes mentioned among the twenty-five men at the east gate of the LORD's house?
options: Jaazaniah son of Azur and Pelatiah son of Benaiah
Ezekiel son of Buzi and Pelatiah son of Benaiah
Azariah son of Jaazaniah and Benaiah son of Pelatiah
Jaazaniah son of Pelatiah and Benaiah son of Azur
questions.correctAnswer: Jaazaniah son of Azur and Pelatiah son of Benaiah
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:1 specifically names Jaazaniah son of Azur and Pelatiah son of Benaiah as princes among the men at the east gate.

questions.question: What metaphor is used in Ezekiel 11 to describe the city and its inhabitants who devise mischief?
options: The city is a caldron and the people are the flesh
The city is a vineyard and the people are the grapes
The city is a fortress and the people are the walls
The city is a sheepfold and the people are the sheep
questions.correctAnswer: The city is a caldron and the people are the flesh
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:3 describes the city as a caldron and the inhabitants as the flesh, symbolizing a place of judgment and destruction.

questions.question: What was the Spirit of the LORD's command to Ezekiel regarding the men at the gate?
options: Prophesy against them
Bless them
Ignore them
Join them
questions.correctAnswer: Prophesy against them
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:4 commands the son of man (Ezekiel) to prophesy against the men who devise wicked counsel.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 11, why will the LORD bring a sword upon the people?
options: Because they feared the sword
Because they worshipped idols
Because they built houses
Because they fled the city
questions.correctAnswer: Because they feared the sword
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:8 states that the people feared the sword, and as a consequence, the LORD will bring a sword upon them.

questions.question: What significant event occurred when Ezekiel prophesied, as recorded in this chapter?
options: Pelatiah son of Benaiah died
Jaazaniah son of Azur repented
The city was destroyed
The Spirit left Ezekiel
questions.correctAnswer: Pelatiah son of Benaiah died
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:13 records the death of Pelatiah son of Benaiah at the moment Ezekiel prophesied.

questions.question: What promise does the LORD make regarding the scattered house of Israel?
options: He will gather them from the countries and give them the land of Israel
He will leave them among the heathen forever
He will punish them with famine and plague
He will transform them into a great nation in Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: He will gather them from the countries and give them the land of Israel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:17 promises that God will gather Israel from the nations and restore them to their land.

questions.question: What transformation does God promise to give the people according to Ezekiel 11?
options: A new heart and a new spirit replacing the stony heart
A golden crown and everlasting kingdom
A mighty army and great riches
A prophetic gift and long life
questions.correctAnswer: A new heart and a new spirit replacing the stony heart
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:19 says God will remove the stony heart and give a heart of flesh and a new spirit.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the new heart and spirit given by God to the people?
options: That they may walk in God's statutes and keep His ordinances
That they may conquer their enemies by force
That they may prosper materially
That they may build new houses
questions.correctAnswer: That they may walk in God's statutes and keep His ordinances
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:20 explains the new heart and spirit are given so the people will obey God's laws and be His people.

questions.question: True or False: The glory of the LORD departed from the city and stood upon the mountain east of the city.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:23 states that the glory of the LORD went up from the midst of the city and stood on the east mountain.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 11, what is the significance of the city not being the caldron nor the people the flesh anymore?
options: It indicates judgment will occur at Israel's border instead
It implies the city will be destroyed immediately
It means the people will become flesh for sacrifice
It signifies the city will become a sanctuary
questions.correctAnswer: It indicates judgment will occur at Israel's border instead
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:11 explains that judgment will happen at the border of Israel, not in the city as a caldron, implying exile or removal from the city.

questions.question: What literary device is evident in the repeated reference to the city as a 'caldron' and the people as 'flesh'?
options: Metaphor
Simile
Hyperbole
Personification
questions.correctAnswer: Metaphor
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:3 and 11:7 use metaphor to represent the city as a caldron and the people as flesh being cooked or judged.

questions.question: How does the promise of a new heart in Ezekiel 11:19-20 connect to New Testament themes?
options: It foreshadows the spiritual renewal through Christ's indwelling Spirit
It predicts the physical resurrection of Israel
It symbolizes the building of the physical temple
It refers to judgment by Roman authorities
questions.correctAnswer: It foreshadows the spiritual renewal through Christ's indwelling Spirit
questions.explanation: The new heart and spirit promise echoes New Testament teachings on transformation by the Holy Spirit (cf. Ezekiel 36:26; 2 Corinthians 3:3).

questions.question: Which historical context is crucial for understanding the judgment pronounced in Ezekiel 11?
options: The Babylonian exile and Jerusalem's impending fall
The Egyptian bondage of Israel
The conquest of Canaan under Joshua
The reign of King David
questions.correctAnswer: The Babylonian exile and Jerusalem's impending fall
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11 reflects the context of Israel's exile to Babylon and the destruction of Jerusalem as divine judgment.

questions.question: What role do the cherubims and their wings play in the vision described in Ezekiel 11?
options: They lift up the glory of the God of Israel as it departs the city
They attack the wicked princes with fire
They guard the east gate from enemies
They bring the new heart to the people
questions.correctAnswer: They lift up the glory of the God of Israel as it departs the city
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:22 describes cherubims lifting their wings and the glory of God rising above them, symbolizing God's departure.

questions.question: What is the significance of the Spirit bringing Ezekiel to the east gate of the LORD’s house in the vision?
options: The east gate faces the direction of the rising sun, symbolizing judgment and exile
It was the gate of entry for foreign kings
It was the only gate left open in the city
It represented the entrance to the underworld
questions.correctAnswer: The east gate faces the direction of the rising sun, symbolizing judgment and exile
questions.explanation: The east gate, facing east as in Ezekiel 11:1, often symbolizes beginnings and God’s presence but here is linked with judgment and exile.

theological.title: Ezekiel Chapter 11 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Ezekiel Chapter 11 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: Who were the two princes among the twenty-five men at the east gate of the LORD's house?
options: Jaazaniah the son of Azur and Pelatiah the son of Benaiah
Azariah the son of Zadok and Eliakim the son of Hilkiah
Nathaniel the son of Levi and Zadok the son of Azur
Pelatiah the son of Azur and Jaazaniah the son of Benaiah
questions.correctAnswer: Jaazaniah the son of Azur and Pelatiah the son of Benaiah
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:1 identifies these two men specifically as princes among the twenty-five at the east gate. Their roles symbolize leadership corrupted by evil counsel, aligning with other biblical examples of leaders responsible for the people's direction (e.g., 2 Kings 25:18; Jeremiah 37:3).

questions.question: What did the men at the gate say about the future of the city?
options: It is not near; let us build houses
The sword will surely come upon us
The Lord will protect us forever
We must repent and seek God
questions.correctAnswer: It is not near; let us build houses
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:3 records these men’s false assurance that the calamity is far off, prompting complacency in sin. This mirrors Israel's historical rejection of divine warnings (Jeremiah 5:12; Hosea 12:1) and illustrates human denial in the face of judgment.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 11, what metaphor is used to describe the city and its people?
options: The city is the caldron, and the people are the flesh
The city is a vineyard, and the people are grapes
The city is a fortress, and the people are stones
The city is a temple, and the people are priests
questions.correctAnswer: The city is the caldron, and the people are the flesh
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:3 and 11:7 use this metaphor to signify the city boiling with violence and sin, with the inhabitants as the flesh being cooked, symbolizing impending judgment. This image recalls God's judgment as refining or purifying (Malachi 3:2; Isaiah 1:25).

questions.question: What is the Lord's response to the wicked counsel and multiplied slain in the city?
options: He will bring a sword upon them and judge them
He will protect the city from destruction
He will forgive them without judgment
He will deliver them immediately
questions.correctAnswer: He will bring a sword upon them and judge them
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:8-10 reveals God's righteous judgment through the sword as a consequence of sin and violence. This corresponds with biblical theology that God’s justice punishes unrepentant sin (Romans 13:4; Deuteronomy 32:35).

questions.question: What does God promise to give the scattered house of Israel?
options: A new heart and a new spirit
Wealth and power in foreign lands
Immediate freedom without repentance
An unchanging stony heart
questions.correctAnswer: A new heart and a new spirit
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:19 promises God will replace the stony heart with a heart of flesh and give a new spirit, signifying spiritual renewal and regeneration, a central theme in biblical salvation (Ezekiel 36:26; Jeremiah 31:33; 2 Corinthians 5:17).

questions.question: Why does God say He will judge the inhabitants of Jerusalem in the border of Israel rather than in the city?
options: Because the city shall no longer be their caldron nor they the flesh therein
Because the city is too holy for judgment
Because He wants them to escape judgment
Because a foreign nation will judge them
questions.correctAnswer: Because the city shall no longer be their caldron nor they the flesh therein
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:11 explains this judgment location shift, symbolizing that Jerusalem will no longer be their place of refuge or security. This echoes the biblical motif of exile and judgment outside the promised land (Jeremiah 25:9; Deuteronomy 28:64).

questions.question: What reason does God give for judging the people of Israel?
options: They have not walked in His statutes and have followed the customs of surrounding nations
They have worshiped Him alone and obeyed His laws
They have been faithful despite hardships
They have destroyed idolatry completely
questions.correctAnswer: They have not walked in His statutes and have followed the customs of surrounding nations
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:12 states their disobedience and adoption of heathen practices as the cause for judgment, consistent with the biblical principle that idolatry and covenant unfaithfulness bring divine discipline (Exodus 20:3-5; Judges 2:11-19).

questions.question: What happened immediately after Ezekiel prophesied against the men at the gate?
options: Pelatiah the son of Benaiah died
Jaazaniah repented and fled
The city was spared from destruction
Ezekiel was taken away in a vision
questions.correctAnswer: Pelatiah the son of Benaiah died
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:13 records Pelatiah's death as a direct consequence of the prophecy, demonstrating the certainty and immediacy of God's judgment, similar to other prophetic narratives where judgment follows pronouncement (1 Kings 13:24; Jeremiah 20:9).

questions.question: What does God declare He will be to His scattered people in the countries where they dwell?
options: A little sanctuary
A distant memory
An angry judge
An indifferent bystander
questions.correctAnswer: A little sanctuary
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:16 emphasizes God's protective presence for His people even in exile, reflecting the covenantal promise that God remains with His people despite judgment (Psalm 46:1; Isaiah 8:14).

questions.question: What will the people do when they return to the land of Israel according to Ezekiel 11?
options: Remove all detestable things and abominations
Build more houses and ignore God
Continue in their sinful ways
Worship foreign gods openly
questions.correctAnswer: Remove all detestable things and abominations
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:18 promises a purifying return where idolatry is removed. This fits the biblical theme of restoration and holiness central to God’s kingdom (Ezra 10:3; Nehemiah 13:30; Isaiah 52:11).

questions.question: What does God say will happen to those whose hearts continue after their detestable things and abominations?
options: He will recompense their way upon their own heads
They will be forgiven without repentance
They will be exalted among the nations
They will receive a new heart and spirit
questions.correctAnswer: He will recompense their way upon their own heads
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:21 affirms the justice of God in recompensing those who persist in sin, consistent with the biblical doctrine of divine retribution (Galatians 6:7; Romans 2:6; Proverbs 11:31).

questions.question: What significant movement of God's glory is described at the end of Ezekiel 11?
options: The glory of the LORD went up from the midst of the city and stood on the mountain east of the city
The glory of the LORD filled the temple and never left
The glory of the LORD descended into the sanctuary
The glory of the LORD went into exile with the people
questions.correctAnswer: The glory of the LORD went up from the midst of the city and stood on the mountain east of the city
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:23 records the departure of God's glory from the city, symbolizing divine judgment and abandonment due to sin, paralleling themes in Exodus 33:18-23 and the New Testament concept of God's presence with His people (John 1:14).

questions.question: To whom was Ezekiel taken in vision after the departure of God’s glory from Jerusalem?
options: To the land of Chaldea, to the captives
To Mount Sinai
To the temple in Jerusalem
To the land of Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: To the land of Chaldea, to the captives
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:24 shows the Spirit bringing Ezekiel to Babylon (Chaldea) to deliver God’s message to the exiled community, highlighting the prophetic call to minister to God's people in captivity (Jeremiah 29:4-7; Daniel 9:2).

questions.question: What is the primary reason the inhabitants of Jerusalem told the house of Israel to "Get you far from the LORD"?
options: They claimed the land was given to them in possession
They wanted to worship the LORD in unity
They sought to protect the house of Israel
They desired to follow God’s statutes faithfully
questions.correctAnswer: They claimed the land was given to them in possession
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:15 explains that the inhabitants of Jerusalem rejected the house of Israel by claiming the land for themselves, reflecting division and covenant unfaithfulness, similar to Israel’s fractured relationship with God and one another (Genesis 13:7; Isaiah 5:8).

questions.question: What does Ezekiel cry out after Pelatiah's death?
options: "Ah Lord GOD! wilt thou make a full end of the remnant of Israel?"
"Praise the Lord for His mercy and grace"
"Let us build houses and live in peace"
"The sword has passed over us"
questions.correctAnswer: "Ah Lord GOD! wilt thou make a full end of the remnant of Israel?"
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 11:13 shows Ezekiel’s lament over the judgment striking the remnant, expressing concern for God’s people, aligning with the biblical motif of intercession and prophetic lament (Exodus 32:11-14; Jeremiah 18:19-23).
